benchmark_details.name: ARGUS (Hallucination and Omission Evaluation in Video-LLMs)
benchmark_details.overview: ARGUS is a benchmark that measures freeform video captioning performance in Video Large Language Models (VideoLLMs) by quantifying rates of hallucinations and omissions in generated video captions compared to human ground truth.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate hallucination and omission rates in freeform captions generated by VideoLLMs, providing a fair platform for benchmarking.

data.source: 500 videos curated from video understanding datasets, text-to-video generation datasets, and Creative Commons sources.
data.annotation: Manually annotated with cross-validation among the authors.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on matching generated captions to human captions using a dynamic programming formulation to minimize hallucination costs.
methodology.interpretation: Lower ArgusCost values indicate better performance with fewer hallucinations and omissions.
methodology.baseline_results: Evaluation across 23 video models shows variable performance influenced by model characteristics.
methodology.validation: Performance results validated using a human evaluation study with high agreement rates.
